abstract: French law enforcement arrest about 100 people after employing law passed in November 2014 that dictates tough prison sentences to those speaking in support of terrorism; raises debate about double standard regarding free speech, which allows cartoonists to poke fun at religions, but criminalizes Muslims speaking in support of gunmen.
lead_paragraph: Recent court cases in Paris have raised accusations of a double standard on free speech with some pointing to a divide between cartoonists and statements made by Muslim supporters of the gunmen.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Maïa de la Baume, Daphne Anglès and Yann Cres from Paris, Alison Smale from Berlin, Sebnem Arsu from Istanbul, Raphael Minder from Madrid, James Kanter from Brussels, and Elisabetta Povoledo from Rome.
byline.original: By DOREEN CARVAJAL and ALAN COWELL

snippet: Recent court cases in Paris have raised accusations of a double standard on free speech with some pointing to a divide between cartoonists and statements made by Muslim supporters of the gunmen.

headline.main: French Rein In Speech Backing Acts of Terror
headline.print_headline: French Rein in Speech Backing Acts of Terror
